article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue on Hydroelasticity Theories and Applications

abstract.p: Assuming the wave steepness of the incident waves and the ship motions are small, the second-order weakly-nonlinear hydrodynamic problem of a ship moving with constant forward speed is studied numerically in a consistent way. The boundary value problem is formulated in a body-fixed coordinate system and the perturbation scheme is used. This formulation does not include any derivatives of the velocity potential on the right-hand side of the body-boundary conditions, and thus avoid the difficulties associated with the terms similar to the so-called mj-terms and their derivatives. The second-order sum-frequency wave excitation of ship springing is studied in both monochromatic and bichromatic head-sea waves. Different Froude numbers are considered. A time-domain Higher-Order Boundary Element Method based on cubic shape function is used as a numerical tool. An upstream finite difference scheme is used for longitudinal derivative terms in the free-surface conditions. For a modified Wigley hull in head-sea waves, it is found that the second-order velocity potential gives dominant contribution to second-order wave excitation of ship springing in the wave frequency region where sum-frequency springing occurs. Quadratic velocity terms in the Bernoulli equation have a relatively small contribution. The numerical results also demonstrate strong dependency of the second-order wave excitation of ship springing on the Froude numbers for small wave lengths. The effect of beam and draft is investigated.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, as ships are increasing in size, a lot of interest has been shown in the understanding of springing and whipping of ships, both of which are hydroelastic problems. Hydroelasticity involves the mutual interactions between the structural elasticity and the motion of the surrounding fluid. In the late 1970s, the study on hydroelasticity of ships first gained momentum with the pioneering work of Bishop and Price on the two-dimensional (2D) hydroelasticity of ships in waves using strip theory. See their monograph.1 Based on the concept of hydroelasticity, a general linear three-dimensional (3D) hydroelasticity theory for an arbitrarily shaped flexible marine structure travelling in a seaway was developed by Wu.2 See also Price and Wu3 and Bishop et al.4 Since then, great progress has been achieved in the development and application of the hydroelasticity theories. A comprehensive overview of the progress of 3D hydroelasticity theories of ships, and the corresponding numerical and experimental techniques, can be found in Wu and Cui.5

Springing of ships is a steady-state wave-induced global hydroelastic resonant vibration, while whipping is a transient and decaying vibration caused by impulsive loading (i.e. slamming). The linear and nonlinear springing loads on ships may strongly reduce the fatigue life of ships. Storhaug6 documented that the springing may contribute approximately 50% of the accumulated fatigue damage based on full-scale measurements of a 300 m bulk carrier. Wave-induced extreme hull girder loading causes important nonlinearities in the design wave bending moment amidships.7 The latter effect is not necessarily dependent on important hydroelastic effects. In the present study, the weakly-nonlinear theory will be used. From a hydrodynamic point of view, slamming-induced whipping is of strong nonlinearity and it is outside the scope of this article.

Linear springing of ships in regular waves occurs when the frequency of encounter matches the natural frequency of 2-node vibration. It implies that the response has the same frequency as the encounter frequency of the incident wave. Linear springing theories were developed by Skjordal and Faltinsen,8 Bishop et al.9 and Maeda.10 Skjordal and Faltinsen8 considered head sea and modified Faltinsen’s11 short wavelength theory which accounts for important 3D flow effects. They found the hydrodynamic forces by solving the diffraction problem and integrated the pressure over the hull surface. Bishop et al.9 and Maeda10 found these forces by formulating a reciprocity relationship and solve the radiation (forced oscillation) problem. Experiments in waves were carried out by Troesch12 on a model jointed amidships, to measure both wave excitation and springing response.

Nonlinear springing has also been observed in regular waves in model tests (see e.g. Storhaug,6 Slocum and Troesch,13 Miyake et al.14) when the encounter frequency is equal to 1/n of the structural natural frequencies where n is integer, i.e. we can talk about second-order, third-order and so on nonlinearly excited springing. If we consider an irregular sea, second-order springing is associated with sum-frequency effects. Wu et al.15 have proposed a 3D nonlinear hydroelasticity theory, where the contributions of the first-order wave potentials and responses to the second-order hydrodynamic actions on a flexible body were formulated. The nonlinearities in the free-surface conditions are not considered. Tian and Wu16,17 have applied this theory to ships travelling in random waves, with a constant forward speed. Vidic-Perunovics and Jensen18 studied theoretically nonlinear springing due to bidirectional waves. The incident waves are described consistently by second-order theory while a pragmatic second-order strip theory is used to describe the interaction with the ship. The effect of nonlinear cross-coupling terms between two long-crested wave systems was added to the second-order terms from each of the two wave systems alone. This was shown to significantly influence the springing-induced response.

It is hard from a numerical point of view to go beyond second-order nonlinearly excited springing by a consistent perturbation scheme. Further, a perturbation scheme becomes increasingly tedious with increasing order of nonlinearly excited springing. Even though the physics behind ship springing has not been fully understood, it is now commonly accepted that springing is essentially a nonlinear phenomenon, meaning that springing response is not related to wave amplitude in a linear way. Miyake et al.14 found experimentally for a modified Wigley model that the springing of super harmonic (n-th) resonance due to the higher-order nonlinear hydrodynamic forces occurred, although the model is a simple mathematical hull form without bulbous bow. The similar phenomenon has been reported by Storhaug6 in his model tests of a bulk carrier with different bow shapes.

The wave-induced sectional loads on ships are often analysed by the blended method which is based on the linear solution with nonlinear corrections for the Froude–Krylov and the restoring forces. Slamming-type of loads may also be added by, for instance, the generalized 2D Wagner approach.19 However, the nonlinearities in the wave radiation and diffraction are not considered in this type of analysis. How important the nonlinear wave radiation/diffraction is as the excitation of nonlinear ship springing still remains a mystery. In order to answer this question, it is necessary to solve a complete higher-order problem (e.g. second-order problem) with the presence of forward speed.

Most of the consistent studies on the second-order sum-frequency wave loads are carried out without considering the forward speed effects. Faltinsen and Løken,20 Lighthill21 and Molin22 obtained the second-order force through a fictitious radiation potential without solving for the second-order velocity potential. However, this technique cannot be used for calculating other quantities such as the hydrodynamic pressure at any point, the sectional force and bending moment or the wave elevation due to the second-order effects. A direct solution of the second-order velocity potential without considering forward speed or current has also been attempted in both the frequency domain and the time domain. The numerical analysis in the frequency domain can be found, for instance, in Molin,22 Løken23 and Kim and Yue.24 With the presence of a weak current, Büchmann25 investigated the second-order wave diffraction by using time-domain boundary element methods (BEMs). The general second-order radiation/diffraction problems with a small forward speed have been studied by Shao and Faltinsen26 in the time domain.

The above-mentioned nonlinear wave radiation/diffraction problems extensively studied in the literature are more relevant for stationary marine structures. These structures may also experience small currents or slow-drift velocities, which are much smaller compared with the forward speed of a ship travelling in seaway. It is known that the unsteady wave system generated by a ship with reduced frequency τ = ωeU/g > 0.25 is essentially different from that when τ < 0.25. Here ωe is the encounter frequency, U is the forward speed and g is the gravity acceleration. Therefore, the hydrodynamic pressure distribution on the wetted ship hull and thus the wave loads on the ship at moderate forward speed may be very different from that with a small forward speed.

When a seakeeping problem is considered, the interaction of the steady flow and unsteady wave field is accounted for by both the body-boundary condition and the free-surface conditions. The so-called mj-terms in the linear wave–current–body analysis with an inertial coordinate system take into account partly the interaction of steady flow and unsteady wave field through the body-boundary condition. The importance of the mj-terms and related studies has been summarized by for instance Kim.27 When the second-order solution is pursued with a formulation in an inertial coordinate system, it involves the second-order derivatives of the first-order unsteady velocity potential and the second-order and third-order derivatives of the steady velocity potential on the body surface. A lower-order derivative term of the velocity potential can be obtained in the solution method by Stokes theorem which is beneficial from a computational accuracy point of view. In a second-order radiation problem without forward speed, Teng et al.28 used a similar technique to reduce the second-order derivative of the velocity potential in the integral equation by one. The cost of doing so in Teng et al.’s28 analysis is an additional waterline integral and the evaluation of integrals involving the first-order derivatives and the normal derivative of the first-order derivatives of the Green function. It is not straightforward to generalize the indirect method using Stokes theorem for the integral of third-order derivatives on the body surface. On the other hand, the direct calculation of these higher-order derivatives with desired accuracy seems to be very difficult for typical marine structures, e.g. ships. Since the latter derivative terms are a consequence of a Taylor expansion, they are wrong at sharp corners with interior angles less than 180°.

In order to get rid of the mj-like terms and their derivatives, Shao and Faltinsen29 formulated the boundary value problem (BVP) in the body-fixed coordinate system in the analysis of the weakly-nonlinear wave–body interaction problems without forward speed/current velocity. This formulation was later extended to include small forward speeds or weak current by Shao and Faltinsen.26 This method has recently been refined by Shao and Faltinsen30 to study the seakeeping problems of ships travelling in waves with moderate forward speeds. In the present study, we will use the formulation in the body-fixed coordinate system, considering its merits. A perturbation method is used so that the computational domain remains unchanged. A cubic-order 3D Higher-Order Boundary Element Method (HOBEM)31 in the time domain is adopted. Taking a modified Wigley hull as an example, we studied the sum-frequency wave excitation of nonlinear ship springing in the wave frequency region that is of interest. The influence of beam and draft has been considered. The generalized second-order excitation of 2-noded mode in the vertical plane is considered. Both monochromatic and bichromatic head-sea waves are studied with different Froude numbers. Interestingly, the numerical results show that the second-order velocity potential gives dominant contribution to the second-order wave excitation of ship springing in the wave frequency region where sum-frequency springing occurs. Furthermore, our numerical results demonstrate strong dependency of the second-order wave excitation of ship springing on the Froude numbers for small wave lengths.

sec.title: Definitions
sec.p: As shown in Figure 1, we define four right-handed Cartesian coordinate systems, i.e. OeXeYeZe, OXYZ, oxyz and ogxgygzg. OeXeYeZe is Earth-fixed with XeYe-plane on the calm water surface and the Ze-axis positive upwards. OXYZ is an inertial coordinate system moving with the steady forward speed of the body. The XY-plane coincides with the XeYe-plane and the Z-axis is parallel to the Ze-axis. oxyz is a body-fixed coordinate system which moves with not only the steady forward speed but also the unsteady rigid-body motions of the body. The z-axis goes through the centre of gravity (COG). When the body is without unsteady motions, oxyz coincides with OXYZ with the origin on the mean free surface. The ogxgygzg is an inertial coordinate system with origin located on the COG, with its axis parallel to that of OXYZ. The body is normally assumed to have the oxz-plane as a plane of symmetry.

Let us define the translatory motion vector of the origin of oxyz relative to the origin of OXYZ, i.e. Oo→, to be ξ→=(ξ1,ξ2,ξ3) so that ξ1 is the surge, ξ2 is the sway and ξ3 is the heave. In addition, we define the Euler angles α4, α5 and α6 about the X-, Y- and Z-axis respectively so that α4 is the roll, α5 is the pitch and α6 is the yaw.

When the water is assumed incompressible and inviscid, and the flow is irrotational, the water motion can be described by a scalar ϕ which is defined as the velocity potential. ϕ satisfies the Laplace equation

in the water domain. The water has infinite horizontal extent and depth. Since we are going to use a perturbation scheme in the following analysis, the amplitudes of the incident waves and the oscillatory body motions relative to the characteristic body dimensions are assumed asymptotically small in the incident wave slope. Therefore, the velocity potential, wave elevation, and body motions can be written as series expansions. The order of Euler angles is, of course, arbitrary. In the present study, the order of Euler angles is taken as yaw, pitch and roll. The difference when a different order is used is expected to be small for small angular body motions. This article studies some special cases, in which the ships have only heave and pitch motions. Indeed, the order of Euler angles does not matter at all for these cases.

The transformation matrix Rb→i that transforms the representation of a vector in the body-fixed oxyz system to its representation in the inertial OXYZ system is given in Appendix 1.

The free-surface conditions equations (2) and (3) are then approximated by introducing Stokes expansion and Taylor expanding the free-surface conditions about the oxy-plane. One should note that the oxy-plane is not necessarily the same as the calm water surface, i.e. the OXY-plane in Figures 1 and 2. The oxy-plane coincides with the calm water surface when the body is at rest, and translates and rotates with the body. As shown in Figure 2, a point P0 initially on the calm water surface will move to point P due to unsteady rigid-body motions. A truncated Taylor expansion will not be valid if the distance |P0P| is not small compared with the characteristic dimensions of the ship (i.e. length, beam and draft), which may occur at a point far away from the body undergoing pitch/roll motions with finite amplitudes. If that happens, how could we use the body-fixed coordinate system in the whole computational domain? Our arguments are as follows. The perturbation scheme assumes that the wave amplitude and body motions are asymptotically small. In that sense, if we truncate the computational domain at a finite distance away from the body, the displacement of a point fixed on the oxy-plane (e.g. |P0P| in Figure 2) would always be small compared with the dimensions of the ship. On the other hand, if asymptotic theory is used, the Response Amplitude Operators (RAOs) of the linear results and the Quadratic Transfer Functions (QTFs) of the second-order results are independent of the wave amplitudes and the ship motions. How good the asymptotic theory is needs comparison with experiments. However, experiences in ship and offshore hydrodynamics showed that the asymptotic theories are very powerful tools.

The free-surface elevation observed in the body-fixed coordinate system has two contributions. The first part is due to the rigid-body motions. It can be understood as follows. When the water is calm, i.e. no incoming or scattered waves, the calm water surface has a relative motion observed in the body-fixed reference frame due to the unsteady body motions. The other contribution is associated with the wave motion with the mentioned rigid-body motion effect excluded. sec.title: Forces and moments calculation
sec.p: Pressure integration is used to get the hydrodynamic forces and moments acting on the body. The pressure needed is given by the Bernoulli equation. However, the Bernoulli equation is a result of integrating the Euler equations, which are only valid in an inertial system, so we can not directly apply it to an accelerated system. It is important to keep in mind that the ∂ϕ/∂t-term in the inertial coordinate system means the time derivative of ϕ for a fixed point with coordinate (X, Y, Z) in the inertial coordinate system. However, in the body-fixed coordinate system we want to operate with the time derivative of ϕ for a fixed point (x, y, z) in the body-fixed system. The relationship between the time derivative in the body-fixed system and that in the inertial system can be written as32
where v→b=ξ→·′+ω→′×r→′ is the velocity at a point (x, y, z) due to rigid-body motions. ξ→·′ and ω→′ are the translatory and angular velocity, respectively. ∇ means spatial gradient.

Transforming the time derivative in the inertial coordinate system into the time derivative in the body-fixed reference frame, and integrating the pressure on the body surface, we can express the forces F→ and moments M→ in either the inertial coordinate system or the body-fixed coordinate system. The expressions for the force and moment calculations are given in Appendix 3.

sec.title: Description of the incident wave field in the body-fixed coordinate system
sec.p: In all the numerical analysis that will be presented in the section on Numerical studies on Wigley hulls, the first-order and second-order incident wave field are prescribed and only the scattered wave field will be solved as unknowns. The total hydrodynamic forces are the sum of the Froude–Krylov force due to incident waves and the force due to the scattered waves. The second-order scattered waves include not only the interaction between the linear incident waves and the linear scattered waves, but also self-interaction of the linear scattered waves.

The description of the regular and irregular incident wave consistent to second order in the inertial coordinate system can be found in Dean and Dalrymple33 and Dalzell,34 respectively. However, when the BVP is formulated in body-fixed reference frame, the description of the incident wave field in the body-fixed coordinate system is needed which satisfies the free-surface conditions equations (6) and (7) when all the terms associated with the steady velocity potential ϕ(0) are set equal to zero.

If we define the velocity potential and wave elevation in the inertial coordinate system as ϕinc,i(k) and ηinc,i(k), and that in the body-fixed coordinate system as ϕinc,b(k) and ηinc,b(k) (k = 1, 2) respectively, the following relationships can be established:

sec.title: HOBEM
sec.p: As shown in the section on Formulation of BVP in the body-fixed coordinate system, we have approximated the free-surface conditions and body-boundary condition on the xy-plane and the mean wetted ship hull, respectively. Therefore, the computational domain enclosed by the mean wetted body surface (SB), the oxy-plane (SF), and a control surface (Sinf) away from the ship is time-invariant. Applying the Green’s third identity in the computational domain gives a boundary integral equation (BIE). A time-domain HOBEM is used to solve the BIE. The computational domain is truncated at a certain distance away from the ship and a damping zone is applied at the outer layer of the free surface, so that most of the energy of the scattered waves is damped out when they travel through the damping zone. Therefore, the contribution of the integrals on Sinf can be neglected.

The boundary surfaces are discretized by a number of 12-node cubic-order boundary elements. In each element, the variables (e.g. velocity potential, velocity and wave elevation) are fitted by piecewise third-order polynomials. The Rankine source (or simple 1/r with r as the distance between source and field point) is chosen as the Green function. Dipoles and sources (or sinks) with unknown strengths are distributed on the free surface and the body surface, respectively.

NOD is the total number of the nodes. δik is the Kronecker delta function. s = IEP(e, j) is a coefficient of the connectivity matrix, which represents the global index of the j-th node of the e-th element. Ci is the solid angle at the i-th node. |Je(ξ,η)| is the Jacobian on the e-th element. The superscript e indicates that the integrals are over the e-th element.

Special care should be taken when calculating the diagonal terms of the influence coefficients. When the field point xi is on the surface of the element, the field point and singularity point may coincide to generate singularities 1/r(x,xi)→∞ and 1/r2(x,xi)→∞. Most of the singularities can be removed by using polar coordinate system on the local element and locating the coordinate origin at the singular point. However, this transformation yields still another singularity 1/ρ in the term H^ije when IEP(e, j) = i (see e.g. Liu et al.36). Here ρ is the radial coordinate. For elements with non-zero curvature, the Cauchy Principle Value (CPV) integral in the diagonal term Hii on a single element does not exist. However, the sum of the integrals in all the elements surrounding the singularity point must exist. In this article, a direct method based on triangular polar-coordinate transformation technique is followed to evaluate the CPV integral in the diagonal term Hii. A similar technique has been proposed by Teng et al.37 based on polar-coordinate transformation. The solid angle Ci is also calculated directly based a method given in Montic.38 More details about the HOBEM used in this study can be found in Shao.31

sec.title: Time integration and the instabilities
sec.p: An explicit fourth-order Runge–Kutta (RK4) method is applied in the time integration of the free-surface conditions. At each time step, the velocity potential is known on the free surface while the normal velocity is given by the body-boundary conditions. Consequently, the HOBEM solver provides normal velocity and velocity potential on the free surface and body surface, respectively. In order to enforce the continuity of velocity potential at the intersection lines of different surfaces where the normal vector is ill-defined, the double-node technique (see for instance Grilli and Svendsen39) has been used. This brings modifications to the corresponding lines of equations in equation (14) and gives us the final algebraic equation system.

In the time-domain simulation of the free-surface waves, two sorts of instabilities are seen when time-integrating the free-surface conditions. The first instability leads to continuously increasing wave amplitudes destroying the solution. The other one leads to stable saw-tooth behaviour of small wave lengths. In this study, the first instability is avoided by choosing a proper combination of the time-marching scheme and the finite difference (FD) schemes for the spatial derivatives.

In order to find a scheme with larger stability region, we have used the Fourier–von Neumann stability analysis40 for different FD schemes combined with the time-marching schemes. The non-dimensional linearized free-surface conditions without steady velocity potential and the body motion effects are considered in the stability analysis as a first approximation. Other matters, e.g. the aspect ratio of elements and the presence of steady velocity potential, which are not considered in the present stability analysis, will also influence the stability. The Fourier–von Neumann stability analysis was only used as a general guidance of choosing the FD scheme and time increments. Based on the stability analysis, it was then decided to use three-point upwind FD scheme for the longitudinal derivative terms in the free-surface conditions. The other derivatives are still based on cubic shape functions.

In order to suppress the saw-tooth behaviour, a low-pass filter is implemented and applied on the collocation points at the waterline and on points adjacent to these. In this study, a three-point low-pass filter is adopted

Here j is a local numbering of the collocation points in the longitudinal or transverse direction. c is the strength of the filter. wj and w¯j are either the velocity potential or the wave elevation before and after smoothing. This low-pass filter was applied by Büchmann25 successfully in the second-order wave diffraction with a weak current based on linear BEM, and later by Shao31 in second-order radiation/diffraction with small forward speeds based on time-domain HOBEM.

Büchmann25 and Shao31 found it sufficient to apply the filter only to the wave elevation η(k) (k = 1, 2). In the present study, when the three-point upwind FD scheme was used which can suppress part of the saw-tooth instability, we found that the saw-tooth instability does not cause visible influences to the linear wave forces and responses of the ship studied in this article. Physically, it can be understood that the wave lengths of the short waves due to the saw-tooth instability are too short to excite the ship.

Taking the Fourier transformation of the filter in equation (19) enables us to study the damping effects of the low-pass filter for different wave lengths. For example, the low-pass filters with c = 0.04, 0.08 and 0.12 damp the amplitude of the linear wave with wave length 20Δx by 0.392%, 0.783% and 1.175%, respectively. Correspondingly, they reduce the amplitude of the short wave (with wave length 2Δx) by 16%, 32% and 48%, respectively.

In this article, the low-pass filter is applied to the first- and second-order wave elevations with filter strength c = C1≈0.0–0.04 and the spatial derivatives of the first-order quantities in the second-order forcing terms (i.e. equations (37) and (38)) with filter strength c = C2≈0.04–0.12. The low-pass filter is applied at each time step in order to suppress the possible growth and propagation of the numerical short waves.

A filter should be able to suppress the instabilities without affecting the physical solution. On the other hand, the solution should not depend on the chosen value of filter strength as long as it is small enough. Numerical results must eventually be shown to be insensitive to the filtering and some results in the section on Convergence studies will demonstrate that.

However, this indicates the increase of CPU time in the time-domain analysis, because each iteration needs a call of the BEM solver. A natural modification to equation (23) is to move the dy/dt terms on the right-hand side to the left-hand side. The latter terms are associated with the impulsive terms in the hydrodynamic forces that are proportional to the acceleration. It means that one can obtain a stable form of the motion equations by simply adding infinite-frequency added mass A∞ terms on both sides of the equations. Consequently, the resulting body-motion equations will take the form of equation (22) instead of equation (23).

sec.title: Numerical studies on Wigley hulls
sec.p: The accuracy of the nonlinear time-domain HOBEM solver used in this article have been documented in our previous works26,29,31 by studying different second-order wave diffraction/radiation problems on structures with/without small forward speeds. The method has also been used by Shao and Faltinsen30 in the numerical seakeeping analysis, showing encouraging agreement with the experiments and other numerical results. For non-small forward speeds cases, we are not able to find any theoretical nonlinear studies to verify our numerical model. Instead, convergence studies with respect to mesh density, time increment, size of the computational domain and the strengths of the low-pass filter have been made.

Our focus in the present study is the second-order wave excitation of springing of ships in monochromatic waves and bichromatic wave. Modified Wigley hull in head-sea waves is considered. The modified Wigley hull is a simple mathematical ship form without bulbous bow. However, it has been reported that nonlinear springing occurred on this ship form.14

An example of the meshes on half of the free surface and wetted mean ship hull is shown in Figure 4(a) and (b), respectively. In order to use the upwind schemes for the spatial derivatives, we have adopted rectangular mesh resolution on the free surface. The meshes are finer near the waterline and gradually become coarse away from the ship.

sec.p: When it comes to the size of the truncated free surface, the numerical results showed that for the considered wave frequency range, it is sufficient to use one ship length upstream of the ship, three ship lengths downstream of the ship and three ship lengths in the transverse direction. When the reduced frequency τ = ωeU/g is slightly above 0.25, the reflected waves from the downstream boundary have negligible effects since they travel with group velocities slower than the ship forward speed. The numerical results are most sensitive to the length of the truncated free surface in the transverse direction. How large the transverse length of the truncated free surface should be depends on, for instance, the forward speed and the encounter frequency. Figure 5 shows a time history of pitch angle of the modified Wigley hull in head sea with Fr=U/gL=0.18. Here U is the forward speed. The ship is restrained from surging and free to heave and pitch. L = 2λ is used in the calculations with λ as the linear incident wave length. In order to investigate the influence of the size of the truncated free surface, the damping zone is switched off in the analysis. The results for different lengths (Ly = 0.5λ, Ly = 1.0λ, and Ly = 2.0λ) of the truncated free surface in the transverse direction are compared. It is seen for this specific case that it is sufficient to use Ly ≥ 1.0λ, while wave reflection from the boundary of the truncated free surface has a clear influence on the results when Ly is as small as 0.5λ.

Figure 6 shows the time history of the second-order vertical force F3(2) on the ship with different meshes densities. Fr = 0.2 and λ/L = 0.5 are considered. NE0 is the number of cubic elements along the ship length. The results for NE0 = 40 and 50 are almost identical, indicating that NE0 = 40 has been sufficient. However, NE0 = 55 will be used in the numerical analysis in the following section, where ships with a different beam are studied. In general, the flow around blunt ships has higher density of streamlines near the body and requires finer meshes. In Figure 7 we have compared F3(2) for different time increments for the time marching. It can be seen that 60 time steps per period is able to obtain acceptably accurate results.

The influences of the low-pass filters on the free surface are also investigated. Firstly, the filter strength for the spatial derivatives of the first-order quantities in the second-order forcing terms is fixed as C2 = 0.08. The second-order results does not show sensitivity to different C1 values when C1≈0.0–0.04, as is demonstrated in Figure 8. On the other hand, when the filter strength for η(k) (k = 1, 2) is fixed as C1 = 0.02, the difference in F3(2) is negligible for different C2≈0.04–0.12, as shown in Figure 9.

sec.title: Second-order generalized excitation of ship springing
Regular waves
sec.p: For given ship length L, Froude number Fr, wave heading and structural natural frequencies ωn, one can estimate the corresponding wave length when the second-order ship springing occurs. Considering a 300 m ship whose lowest structural natural period is typically around 2 s, travelling in head-sea waves with Fr<∼0.3, we found that the second-order ship springing only occurs in the relatively short wave region, e.g. λ/L ≤ 0.3. λ is the linear incident wave length.

As a starting point, we have studied the second-order wave diffraction of the modified Wigley hull (defined in equations (24) and (25) and Table 1) travelling in the regular head-sea waves with 0.25 ≤ λ/L ≤ 0.5. This enables us to identify the relative importance of the quadratic effects of the linear solution and the second-order velocity potential, as the sources of the excitation of nonlinear ship springing. One should note that springing is a resonant phenomenon, in which the damping sources can be as equally important as the excitation. The discussion on different sources of damping effects can be found in Söding.41 However, the wave excitation is the only focus of this study.

Because the modified Wigley ship studied in this article has vertical surface at the mean waterline, the second integral in equation (26) does not contribute. As the first example, the modified Wigley ship defined in equations (24) and (25) and Table 1 is scaled to full scale with ship length, beam and draft as L = 300 m, B = 30 m and D = 18.75 m, respectively. Presented in Figures 10 to 12 are the results for Fr = 0.18, 0.20 and 0.22, respectively. F7,a(2) is the amplitude of the total generalized second-order excitation of the 2-node mode in the vertical plane. F7,p2(2) and F7,q(2) are the contributions from the second-order velocity potential and the quadratic velocity terms in the Bernoulli equation, respectively. It is immediately apparent that the second-order velocity potential gives dominant contributions relative to the quadratic velocity terms. This is somewhat similar to what we have learnt in the analysis of second-order wave diffraction on a fixed hemisphere. For a submerged hemisphere restrained in waves, Kim42 demonstrated that the contribution of second-order velocity potential dominates over the quadratic velocity term in Bernoulli’s equation in the short wave region, and that it may not be conservative to simply neglect the second-order velocity potential effects in the nonlinear wave diffraction forces analysis. Furthermore, the comparison of the results for different Froude numbers (Fr = 0.18, 0.20, 0.22) also suggests that the second-order excitation has a strong dependence on the Froude number for small wave lengths.

sec.p: Actually, a ship with L = 300 m, B = 30 m and D = 18.75 m represents an unusual ship. Therefore, two other ships with different beam and draft are also studied, both of which are scaled from the modified Wigley ship defined in equations (24) and (25) and Table 1. The first ship has L = 300 m, B = 48 m and D = 18.75 m, and the other one is with L = 300 m, B = 48 m and D = 11 m. The selection of the ship size is based on a bulk carrier studied by Storhaug.6 The deep and shallow drafts represent cargo and ballast conditions, respectively. Fr = 0.18 is considered. The results for second-order excitation of springing are shown in Figures 13 and 14. Comparing Figure 10 and Figure 13, we see that the blunt ship suffers higher second-order springing excitation relative to the slender ship. This may be explained by the fact that the blunt ship generates a stronger scattered wave, which in return interacts with the incident wave and itself to give second-order effects. Comparison between Figure 13 and Figure 14 also indicates higher second-order excitation for the ship in ballast load condition, in which case it is easier for the ship bottom to feel the incident wave and cause disturbance. Furthermore, the relative contribution of the quadratic velocity term in Bernoulli’s equation has increased in the ballast condition. However, in the studied wave length region, its contribution is still smaller than that of the second-order velocity potential.

sec.title: Irregular waves
sec.p: When a ship travels in the seaway, the incident waves are irregular containing an infinite number of wave components. Evaluation of second-order sum-frequency wave excitation of ship springing in irregular waves is relevant to the fatigue analysis of the ships.

We consider head sea and assume long-crested waves with a wave energy spectrum Se(ωe) with respect to the encounter frequency ωe. In general, the total sum-frequency generalized excitation of springing can be written as

Here Ai and Aj are incident wave amplitudes of frequency components i and j, respectively. ωe,i and ωe,j are wave frequencies of encounter. βi and βj are the random phase angles of incident waves. ε+(ωe,i,ωe,j) is the phase angle of the generalized excitation due to nonlinear interactions between the i-th wave component, the j-th wave component and the diffracted and radiated waves by the ship. T+ is the QTFs with the wave elevations as input and the generalized excitation force as output. The following symmetry conditions are assumed
A sum-frequency spectral density for the second-order sum-frequency excitation of springing is defined as

Here Ω≥0 and 2Λ≥0 are the sum frequency and difference frequency of two wave components from the wave spectrum Se(ωe), respectively. Therefore, 0.5Ω−Λ and 0.5Ω+Λ are the encounter frequencies of the two waves. Winterstein et al.43 have given a similar definition for zero forward speed.

In order to get the QTFs, i.e. T+(0.5Ω−Λ,0.5Ω+Λ), we have studied the second-order sum-frequency wave excitation of ship springing in bichromatic waves. The linear wave amplitudes of the two wave components are assumed to be same in all the analysis. This does not matter since the QTFs are independent of the incident wave amplitudes. In the simulations, we have set the random phase angles βi and βj in equation (30) equal to zero. What we obtain from this type of time-domain analysis is a time history containing several different frequencies. Specifically, the second-order components may oscillate with circular frequencies 2(0.5Ω−Λ), 2(0.5Ω+Λ), Ω and 2Λ respectively, together with a mean component which does not vary with time. Fourier analysis gives the amplitudes of the sum-frequency excitation with different oscillating frequencies. When the two waves are identical, we have to divide this amplitude by 4 in order to get the correct sum-frequency QTFs for ship springing defined in equation (33). In case the two wave components are different, this amplitude should be divided by 2.

We consider the ship with L = 300 m, B = 30 m and D = 18.75 m. The lowest structural natural period of a real ship with ∼300 m ship length is around 2 s. Therefore, from the wave excitation point of view, it is of interest to consider pairs of waves when the sum of encounter frequencies is close to 2π/2≈3.14 rad/s, i.e. ΩL/g≈17.4.

Depicted in Figure 15(a) are the amplitudes of the second-order sum-frequency transfer function for generalized excitation of 2-node mode in the vertical plane. Corresponding phase angles are shown in Figure 15(b). Head-sea waves are considered with Froude number Fr = 0.178. The ship is free to response in heave and pitch. The results are presented as a function of ΩL/g for various non-dimensional difference frequencies 2ΛL/g≈0, 1.11 and 1.16, corresponding to 2Λ = 0, 0.2 rad/s and 0.3 rad/s, respectively. The numerical results showed that, in the considered frequency range, T+ is in general larger for a high sum frequency than that for a low sum frequency. On the other hand, for a fixed sum-frequency, neither T+ nor ϵ+ shows strong variation with the considered various difference frequencies. This was not the case for tension leg platforms (TLPs). Based on calculations by Molin and Chen,44 Winterstein et al.43 presented numerical results of the amplitude of the second-order transfer function for the pitch moment on the Snorre TLP, showing relatively large difference for various difference frequencies.

sec.title: Concluding remarks and future work
sec.p: A complete second-order problem of a ship travelling in waves is solved numerically by a time-domain HOBEM. Following a perturbation scheme, the BVP is formulated in the body-fixed coordinate system, which avoids higher derivatives in the body-boundary conditions. The second-order sum-frequency wave excitation of ship springing in both monochromatic and bichromatic waves is investigated. In the wave frequency region where sum-frequency springing occurs, the numerical results based on a modified Wigley ship showed that the second-order velocity potential gives dominant contributions relative to the quadratic velocity terms in the Bernoulli equation. For small wave lengths, strong dependency of the second-order wave excitation of ship springing on the Froude numbers are also seen. The described method can be generalized to study the generalized second-order springing excitation in oblique sea by including lateral vibrations. However, a rational damping model has to be derived. As future work, more realistic ships with flares should be studied.

Instead, it means that integral of the pressure effect, e.g. forces and moments, are of zeroth order, first order and second order, respectively. An example is the pressure at the sharp corner. Within the context of potential theory without flow separation, the −1/2ρ∇ϕ(1)·∇ϕ(1) term of p(2) is singular, which means −1/2ρ∇ϕ(1)·∇ϕ(1) and thus p(2) is by no means of O(ε2). However, −1/2ρ∇ϕ(1)·∇ϕ(1) is integrable at the sharp corner. And its contribution to the forces or the moments is of O(ε2).
